Tuesday, September 25 may
very well go down as a landmark
clay in Hopkins' history. A proposal was submitted to Student
Council President Bob Nelson as
well as Dean Columbo, head of
Homewood Schools and Services
to re-establish a student radio station (WHOP) on campus.
The initial set-up cost, according to the prospective radio station (WHOP) president Brian
Liddicoat, would be $12,500,
with an extra $1,000 cost for each
additional building that would
carry the station. The station
would be broadcast through a carrier current which would work
slightly differently than the
typical FM frequency.
Radio transmitters would be
hooked up to a building's power

walls would prevent the electromagnetic current from leaving
the building. This method,
assured Liddicoat, would not interfere with the electrical power
or phone lines of the buildings.

Andy Barnert, Programming
Director Richard Schwartz,
Business Manager Mira Vayda

FM.

basement of AMR II and later
moved to the back of Lazear,

Johns Hopkins University is one of the best premedical institutions in the country. Students interested in going to medical school receive excellent
preparation in key areas. They also receive faculty and administrative support when applying, and
they benefit from having many students of high
academic ability with similar goals in their
program.
Most undergraduates who plan to go to medical
school major in biology. The biology department
at Hopkins prepares students well for medical
school by offering an especially strong background
in biochemistry and cellular biology. Hopkins
students have an extremely high acceptance rate
to medical school, and once there, they are very
successful. These strengths attest to Hopkins' success as a pre-medical institution and offer benefits
to both individual students and the institution as
a whole.
Hopkins undergraduates also benefit from their
contact with current research in biology. The size
and structure of the department allow students to
get involved with faculty members who are at the
top of their fields. Students participate in and contribute to the work in progress within the department. They are a part of the process—not just
observers—and as a result their education extends
beyond the dimensions of classroom learning. They
are engaged in the material and the issues more
intimately, and at a higher level, than is possible
at most institutions.
The attention of the faculty and administration,
the specific strengths and emphasis of the department, and the unique opportunities in research
prepare students extremely well for medical school
or graduate work and research careers in biology.
But the courses offered in the biology department
are limited in scope and cater only to students who
plan to work in these specific areas. Students interested in pursuing careers in the health professions who do not want to attend medical school cannot, in many cases, fulfill the prerequisites for a
professional program during their four years at
Hopkins.
It is not reasonable to expect the biology department at a school of this size to be excellent in all
fields, or even to offer courses in every possible
area of interest. It is reasonable, however, to
assume that students interested in the health pro-

fessions may come here intending to apply to
medical school but later decide against it during
a course of study. It should be possible for a student to make a logical, lateral move within a
general course of study and be able to leave
Hopkins prepared for his or her chosen professional
program.
The strengths of the biology department here at
Hopkins are unique and valuable, but they do not
serve as excuse nor explanation for the lack of options available to students interested in other health
profesions or in an alternative in biology. With attention to the needs of these students, a few courses
could be added to the curriculum. These courses
would address the needs of atypical Hopkins
biology students specifically, but they would also
serve as valuable options for other biology students
and the rest of the University population. Though
not required for entrance to medical school, the
courses would still be of interest to many and highly
relevant to the field. They would also offer greater
choices to students who are interested in basic
natural science courses but who do not have the
background in chemistry to take most of the biology
courses in the current curriculum.
Filling the gaps would not place unreasonable
financial or teaching demands on the department.
It would in no way detract from the strengths of
Hopkins, but it would more closely align the curriculum with those of Hopkins' peer institutions,
and it would directly serve the academic needs and
interests of Hopkins undergraduates.

consistent criticism as Campus Security. Students
at Hopkins absorb the evolving canon of Security

nothing but tool around campus in their oversized
sedans and eat doughnuts. The emergency
telephones that dot the campus connect directly to
the AMR II snack bar—or so the jokes inform us.

Banned Art At BAUhouse
by Steven Lacher
Down on Charles Street,
there's a gallery and museum
called the BAUhouse. It's a place
to see art, art that is disturbing
art that often accurately portrays
our society, and successfully
mocks it. This month, the
BAUhouse features an exhibit
called "Censored/Censured," a
collection of works from the MidAtlantic which at one time or
another were deemed obscene or
unacceptable and banned from
public view.
Upon first walking into the
gallery, I was struck by the nature
of the exhibit. There is something
just not right about these works.
They make your skin crawl. This
is not to say that they are ugly or
grotesque. Rather, they run the
gamut of extremes in sensuality,
graphic bluntness and sheer
horror.
Many of the works are
undeniably sexually explicit, and
some of the topics covered are not
found in the arena of polite
discussion: child abuse, rape, incest, racism. On the other hand,
many of the paintings and
photographs are beautiful. But
what unites these works is the
feeling they collectively express
about our society, a malaise or
discontent with the way we currently are.
One such work, Thomas
Segars' "Patriot," depicts a man
whose eyes are blindfolded. The

blindfold is an American flag.
The painting was at one time
withdrawn from an art show for
being "inappropriate."
"As I watched people scuffling
over burning flags," comments
Segar, "I thought about how
much attention was being paid to
the symbol, and that perhaps
more attention should be paid to
the idea that it's supposed to
represent. Phrases like 'wrapping
himself in the flag' and 'blind

patriotism' came to mind and the
image of the blindfolded man
presented itself to me. Although
perhaps not the world's most
original image, it visualized my
feelings and I painted it."
"Just beneath the deceptively
calm surface of what is often called a free society can lurk a surprisingly turbulent and continuous conflict of ideas, over
such things as the boundaries of
censorship in art, the freedom of

expression, and perhaps even
what thought should be expressed. This was the disturbing part
to learn."
Another censored painting is
Martin Palombo's "The Magician." It depicts two men standing together, one dressed in a
magician's tuxedo, the other
garbed in white. The hair of the
man in white is painted as flames,
and on his shoulders rides a rabbit. In his comments Mr. Patom-

bo actually felt flattered that the
censors who refused his work
couldn't actually give him a
reason why.
"They just wanted it to go
away," he says.
It's a convincing argument
when one views some of the
tamer items in the collection. One
piece was a coloring book of
Washington, D.C. called Color
the Burg, which was banned
because its editors felt "certain

drawings in the book looked
satanic."
Mark Hossfeld, one of the exhibit organizers, feels the art is
"very, very tame."
"A lot of the problem is today's climate," he says "Petty
bureaucrats in a courthouse feel
they can do something by censoring at will."
He feels responsiblity for the
problem lies in part with the
media in which most of this art
is created. Literature, he says,
has been as explicit and sexual as
any of these works, yet the National Endowment for the Arts
has had no qualms about funding
works of writing. He believes the
visceral nature of a visual
message arouses an instinctual
fear of the work. He also doesn't
feel this is a fad issue. "It's going to be around for quite a
while," he says, "and it's going
to get worse before it gets
better."
"It's a question of survival,"
he says. "Without support is it
even economically feasible to
create art at all?"
Yet he has his own solution to
this problem. "View this art," he
says. "Support this art. Rally
around censored artists. And just
make art."

top form at the final MAC

players fresh, but they are
stronger than other teams'
starters," concludes freshman
goalie Joey Molko. "We're really coming together as a team,
which is crucial in water polo."
When asked if the Jays will win
the MAC title, Molko adds,
"Anything less would be a
disappointment."

Johns Hopkins University is one of the best premedical institutions in the country. Students interested in going to medical school receive excellent
preparation in key areas. They also receive faculty and administrative support when applying, and
they benefit from having many students of high
academic ability with similar goals in their
program.
Most undergraduates who plan to go to medical
school major in biology. The biology department
at Hopkins prepares students well for medical
school by offering an especially strong background
in biochemistry and cellular biology. Hopkins
students have an extremely high acceptance rate
to medical school, and once there, they are very
successful. These strengths attest to Hopkins' success as a pre-medical institution and offer benefits
to both individual students and the institution as
a whole.
Hopkins undergraduates also benefit from their
contact with current research in biology. The size
and structure of the department allow students to
get involved with faculty members who are at the
top of their fields. Students participate in and contribute to the work in progress within the department. They are a part of the process—not just
observers—and as a result their education extends
beyond the dimensions of classroom learning. They
are engaged in the material and the issues more
intimately, and at a higher level, than is possible
at most institutions.
The attention of the faculty and administration,
the specific strengths and emphasis of the department, and the unique opportunities in research
prepare students extremely well for medical school
or graduate work and research careers in biology.
But the courses offered in the biology department
are limited in scope and cater only to students who
plan to work in these specific areas. Students interested in pursuing careers in the health professions who do not want to attend medical school cannot, in many cases, fulfill the prerequisites for a
professional program during their four years at
Hopkins.
It is not reasonable to expect the biology department at a school of this size to be excellent in all
fields, or even to offer courses in every possible
area of interest. It is reasonable, however, to
assume that students interested in the health pro-

fessions may come here intending to apply to
medical school but later decide against it during
a course of study. It should be possible for a student to make a logical, lateral move within a
general course of study and be able to leave
Hopkins prepared for his or her chosen professional
program.
The strengths of the biology department here at
Hopkins are unique and valuable, but they do not
serve as excuse nor explanation for the lack of options available to students interested in other health
profesions or in an alternative in biology. With attention to the needs of these students, a few courses
could be added to the curriculum. These courses
would address the needs of atypical Hopkins
biology students specifically, but they would also
serve as valuable options for other biology students
and the rest of the University population. Though
not required for entrance to medical school, the
courses would still be of interest to many and highly
relevant to the field. They would also offer greater
choices to students who are interested in basic
natural science courses but who do not have the
background in chemistry to take most of the biology
courses in the current curriculum.
Filling the gaps would not place unreasonable
financial or teaching demands on the department.
It would in no way detract from the strengths of
Hopkins, but it would more closely align the curriculum with those of Hopkins' peer institutions,
and it would directly serve the academic needs and
interests of Hopkins undergraduates.

Few aspects of the University come under such
consistent criticism as Campus Security. Students
at Hopkins absorb the evolving canon of Security
jokes far more readily than they absorb the fundamentals of any 100-level lecture class. And
what's the surprise in that? Hopkins Security Police
can often seem like dull, bloated caricatures of
"real police." They harass students. They do
nothing but tool around campus in their oversized
sedans and eat doughnuts. The emergency
telephones that dot the campus connect directly to
the AMR II snack bar—or so the jokes inform us.
But what's the issue behind the jokes?

Banned Art At BAUhouse
by Steven Lacher
Down on Charles Street,
there's a gallery and museum
called the BAUhouse. It's a place
to see art, art that is disturbing
art that often accurately portrays
our society, and successfully
mocks it. This month, the
BAUhouse features an exhibit
called "Censored/Censured," a
collection of works from the MidAtlantic which at one time or
another were deemed obscene or
unacceptable and banned from
public view.
Upon first walking into the
gallery, I was struck by the nature
of the exhibit. There is something
just not right about these works.
They make your skin crawl. This
is not to say that they are ugly or
grotesque. Rather, they run the
gamut of extremes in sensuality,
graphic bluntness and sheer
horror.
Many of the works are
undeniably sexually explicit, and
some of the topics covered are not
found in the arena of polite
discussion: child abuse, rape, incest, racism. On the other hand,
many of the paintings and
photographs are beautiful. But
what unites these works is the
feeling they collectively express
about our society, a malaise or
discontent with the way we currently are.
One such work, Thomas
Segars' "Patriot," depicts a man
whose eyes are blindfolded. The

blindfold is an American flag.
The painting was at one time
withdrawn from an art show for
being "inappropriate."
"As I watched people scuffling
over burning flags," comments
Segar, "I thought about how
much attention was being paid to
the symbol, and that perhaps
more attention should be paid to
the idea that it's supposed to
represent. Phrases like 'wrapping
himself in the flag' and 'blind

patriotism' came to mind and the
image of the blindfolded man
presented itself to me. Although
perhaps not the world's most
original image, it visualized my
feelings and I painted it."
"Just beneath the deceptively
calm surface of what is often called a free society can lurk a surprisingly turbulent and continuous conflict of ideas, over
such things as the boundaries of
censorship in art, the freedom of

expression, and perhaps even
what thought should be expressed. This was the disturbing part
to learn."
Another censored painting is
Martin Palombo's "The Magician." It depicts two men standing together, one dressed in a
magician's tuxedo, the other
garbed in white. The hair of the
man in white is painted as flames,
and on his shoulders rides a rabbit. In his comments Mr. Patom-

bo actually felt flattered that the
censors who refused his work
couldn't actually give him a
reason why.
"They just wanted it to go
away," he says.
It's a convincing argument
when one views some of the
tamer items in the collection. One
piece was a coloring book of
Washington, D.C. called Color
the Burg, which was banned
because its editors felt "certain

drawings in the book looked
satanic."
Mark Hossfeld, one of the exhibit organizers, feels the art is
"very, very tame."
"A lot of the problem is today's climate," he says "Petty
bureaucrats in a courthouse feel
they can do something by censoring at will."
He feels responsiblity for the
problem lies in part with the
media in which most of this art
is created. Literature, he says,
has been as explicit and sexual as
any of these works, yet the National Endowment for the Arts
has had no qualms about funding
works of writing. He believes the
visceral nature of a visual
message arouses an instinctual
fear of the work. He also doesn't
feel this is a fad issue. "It's going to be around for quite a
while," he says, "and it's going
to get worse before it gets
better."
"It's a question of survival,"
he says. "Without support is it
even economically feasible to
create art at all?"
Yet he has his own solution to
this problem. "View this art," he
says. "Support this art. Rally
around censored artists. And just
make art."

The Johns Hopkins Men's
Water Polo Team was not-sofashionably late to its September
22nd tournament at Fordham
University in New York. Traffic
was probably the only obstacle
that the squad couldn't overcome,
as it cruised to victory in four of
its five games.
"We arrived late and had to play
with little preparation," says
rookie Coach Craig Silliman of
the opening 14-0 loss to Columbia. "We started poorly, and
then we outplayed them in the second half. From there, we
basically outplayed everybody."
Silliman, who took over the
squad from the departed Jim
Cutrone during the offseason,
seems to have inherited the tools
for an extremely successful campaign. Three seniors--Rob Fitzgerald, Fred Herberich, and

Dave Weiss--provide leadership
and experience. Sophomores Doug
Jones, Mike Zelinan, and Jay
Smith are the future of the squad.
"Mike Zelman was probably
the MVP of the tournament. We
have a lot of experience and an
extremely deep bench, which will
help us in the long tournament
weekends ahead," adds Silliman.
Two of the Jay's victories were
especially significant because
they came against Mid-Atlantic
Conference teams. Johns
Hopkins thrashed St. Peter's by
a count of 17-7 and manhandled
St. Francis 12-7. Fordham and
Bronx Aquatics were the Jays'
other victims.
Cornell is recognized as
Hopkins' toughest competition in
the MAC, but the squad expects
few problems.
"We feel pretty confident that
we can take the conference title,"

states the relaxed coach.
Most likely, the Jays will play
at least thirty games this season
including tournament contests.
Tournaments consist of five to
seven games, played within a
twenty-four to forty-eight hour
period. Due to this grueling
schedule, the team should be in
top form at the final MAC
tournament.
"While other teams are afraid
to go to the bench, we have such
depth that we can substitute
knowing that, not only are our
players fresh, but they are
stronger than other teams'
starters," concludes freshman
goalie Joey Molko. "We're really coming together as a team,
which is crucial in water polo."
When asked if the Jays will win
the MAC title, Molko adds,
"Anything less would be a
disappointment."
